Package id.xfunction

Class XProcess

  • Object
    • XProcess
  • public class XProcess
extends Object

    Wraps standard Process class with convenient methods.

    Some commands may block until you start reading their stdout or stderr. This may be problem when you just want to run a command ignoring its output. Use flush methods in that case.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      XProcess​(Process process)  
      XProcess​(Process process, Stream<String> stdout, Stream<String> stderr, int code)
      This ctor supposed to be used in tests when you want to mock results of XExec

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      int await()
      Waits for process to complete and returns code safely wrapping all checked exceptions to RuntimeException.
      Future<Integer> code()  
      XProcess flush​(boolean ignore)
      Flushes stdout and stderr.
      XProcess flushStderr​(boolean ignore)
      Consumes stderr stream into internal buffer asynchronously.
      XProcess flushStdout​(boolean ignore)
      Consumes stdout stream into internal buffer or ignores it.
      XProcess forward()
      Forwards stdout and stderr to System.out and System.err respectively.
      XProcess forwardStderr()
      Consumes stderr stream and forwards it to System.err This call is async.
      XProcess forwardStdout()
      Consumes stdout stream and forwards it to System.out This call is async.
      Process process()  
      Stream<String> stderr()
      After you consume this stream it will not be longer valid.

        This ctor supposed to be used in tests when you want to mock results of XExec

    • Method Detail

      • stdoutAsString

        public String stdoutAsString()
        Returns standard output as a string. This call will consume stdout stream meaning that you can call it only once. If you want to call it multiple times make sure to flush stdout first and wait until process will finish.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if called more than once
        See Also:
        await

      • flushStdout

        public XProcess flushStdout​(boolean ignore)
        Consumes stdout stream into internal buffer or ignores it. This call is async.

      • forwardStdout

        public XProcess forwardStdout()
        Consumes stdout stream and forwards it to System.out This call is async.

      • stderrAsString

        public String stderrAsString()
        Returns standard error output as a string. This call will consume stderr stream meaning that you can call it only once. If you want to call it multiple times make sure to flush stderr first.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if called more than once
        See Also:
        flushStderr(boolean)

      • flushStderr

        public XProcess flushStderr​(boolean ignore)
        Consumes stderr stream into internal buffer asynchronously. This call is async.

      • forwardStderr

        public XProcess forwardStderr()
        Consumes stderr stream and forwards it to System.err This call is async.

      • flush

        public XProcess flush​(boolean ignore)
        Flushes stdout and stderr.
        See Also:
        flushStderr(boolean), flushStdout(boolean)

      • forward

        public XProcess forward()
        Forwards stdout and stderr to System.out and System.err respectively.
        See Also:
        forwardStderr(), forwardStdout()

      • process

        public Process process()

      • stdout

        public Stream<String> stdout()
        After you consume this stream it will not be longer valid.
        See Also:
        flushStdout(boolean)

      • stderr

        public Stream<String> stderr()
        After you consume this stream it will not be longer valid.
        See Also:
        flushStderr(boolean)

      • code

        public Future<Integer> code()
        Returns:
        process return code

      • await

        public int await()

        Waits for process to complete and returns code safely wrapping all checked exceptions to RuntimeException.

        Make sure to use flush methods if you ignore output/stderr.

        Throws:
        RuntimeException
